setup.question: How many people live on the moon at any one time?
answers: People are coming and going all the time

Text.text: Sounds like something provable by text

The story is set on the moon base with a crew who are replaced every 18 months via a relief ship. 
The current crew are:

i.e. 6
B can confirm this as well. 
The difference between the options is the frequency/ease with which these crew are replaced. 
See this convo between Dahl and Chapman (senior astronaut who's been there the longest)
It isn't feasible for 'people to come and go all the time'. We also have ev for how frustrated they are at having to stay so long, can add in my next turn.
The story is set on the moon where there is some sort of colony that has been established. The issue is that the people who are stationed on the moon hate it, it's described as
. Because of this, everybody who is stationed on the moon wants to leave, and they all try to get a ride on the

s that are constantly making trips btwn Earth and the moon.

Anyone who has a chance to leave takes it, e.g. Chapman, one of the men, rejects an offer to stay fro double his salary bc:

Waiting on whether B can refute the 6 names = 6 persons things.
Also there seems to be pretty clear evidence people can only leave every eighteen months... and that doesn't seem like "all the time"

As B says, the astronauts hate it there. They even offer to double Chapman's salary to stay, but he says no. In fact, actually Chapman had already stayed an extra 18 months (i.e. 3 years) before so he had stayed longer than anyone else. He tells Klein, "
". To which Klein says, "
" and Chapman replies

. 
He regrets staying so long there. People are trying to convince him to stay even longer (c.6534 from B) but he disagrees bc he misses home "
", if folks kept traveling, why would he feel this way?

Just because there are half a dozen Astronauts on the moon in one instance doesn't mean that's how many there are always. As A says, there are crews and ships on a constant schedule going back and forth between Earth and the Moon. Similarly, there are different amounts of crew members on each of the supply runs. That means that the amount of people on the Moon will also vary and just because A has cited 6 names doesn't mean that there will "at any given time" be 6 people on the moon.

This is shown near the end when
arrives with newcomers. The only people actually mentioned are
and
, the
. This clearly isn't 6 people, which disproves A's arg about the ship transport.

A, you need to prove that the people coming replace the ones already there, thus the numbers stay at about half a dozen

B, for your option. Constant schedule also doesn't = all the time? Because there's 18 months when the ship doesn't come and it's just those people

For context, I think we've established that the astronauts hate it on the moon but have to stay for 18ish months + higher-ups are trying to convince Chapman to stay on even longer when the relief crew comes. 
Klein asks why this is needed at all:
To which Chapman replies:

...
The relief crew is meant to 'take over' from the current crew and one existing member might stays on i.e. about the same no. stay on the moon after the switch.
To address B's last point, not all the new crew are named in the passage, just the ones that speak to Chapman.
A concedes that everyone doesn't get replaced, some people stay for longer, sometimes more people leave, as there's always someone who

. This means that my point about it constantly being a cycle of /different amounts/ of people is true. There's never a constant "half a dozen" people on the moon, but rather different people cycle in and out at different times.

Constant schedule just refers to the spaceship, that doesn't mean that there is a constant amount of people on the moon. I've proven that people come and go at different rates which proves that there's never a set amount of people on the moon, which is what A needs to prove.

The option clearly says "about" half a dozen, so no I didn't expect A to be able to answer there's exactly that much

I think A does a good job of explaining the replacement process, some stay to help the new crew
* can you further prove that it's a small number of people?
* use quotes to prove they talk to Chapman bit, and that there might be more/not
so I can be more sure that numbers don't change much and are always around half a dozen

B, I really need you to defend the all the time bit. Any proof that there's more spaceships, or more people, etc?

I'm leaning towards A, but I am still open to changing my mind if there's good evidence or reasoning

For the fact that it's a small number, I think the best fit is when Chapman is talking about what he misses from home (adding to c.2966), he talks about the loneliness and missing people. If there was a large number/frequent replacements, it seems odd that this is what he misses most: "

" 

For the fact that these are the new crew who came to talk to Chapman see here:
Note how B has given part quotes (c.5923, c.5925, c.5927) obfuscating the context (Eberlein == Captain but B actively hid this).

Look, I don't have to prove an arbitrary amount of time for it to be continuous, that would be an untenable burden. I've proven that ships are on a consistent schedule and that the number of people on the moon is varying. This means that there are "people coming and going" from the moon because not everyone leaves and not everyone stays.

Fully reviewing

Opening speech
A quotes 6 names. B says that people want to leave.
Both mention relief ship, B says (with no evidence) that it is constant, A says it is currently at 18 months - which is technically constant just not frequent

2nd Speech
I think A could've been more directly responsive here? And the bit about missing I understand better later? B manages to confuse me with the number of people on relief ship

3rd speech
A clarifies replacement process, yey! So "about 6" makes sense, and B's last sentence about "set" number of people seems off

4th speech
A hits back. B can't seem to recover from that

In retrospect, I might've ended the debate earlier if it wasn't async or A revealed certain things earlier?

answers.reason for outcome: The judge controlled the debate with an iron first until they got the right answer
Because there wasn't really enough evidence to support my side. There were a few killer quotes that A could cite.
Evidence, okay steering of the debate, debater responsiveness/not consistent/not
